Vocative | pítar || pitárau || pitárah |} {{See also|Devi inflection|Vrkis inflection}} ===Numerals=== The numbers from one to ten are: # {{IAST|éka-}} # {{IAST|dvá-}} # {{IAST|trí-}} # {{IAST|catúr-}} # {{IAST|páñca-}} # {{IAST|ṣáṣ-}} # {{IAST|saptá-, sápta-}} # {{IAST|aṣṭá-, áṣṭa-}} # {{IAST|náva-}} # {{IAST|dáśa-}} All numbers in Sanskrit can be declined in all the cases. Numbers above four are only declined in the plural. ''{{IAST|Éka}}'' is declined like a pronominal adjective, though the dual form does not occur. ''{{IAST|Dvá}}'' appears only in the dual. ''{{IAST|Trí}}'' and ''{{IAST|catúr}}'' are declined irregularly:{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} {| class="wikitable" |- !rowspan="2"| !colspan="3"| Three !colspan="3"| Four |- ! Masculine !! Neuter !! Feminine !! Masculine !! Neuter !! Feminine |- ! Nominative | tráyah || trī́ṇi || tisrá || catvā́rah || catvā́ri || cátasra |- ! Accusative | trīn || trī́ṇi || tisrá || catúrah || catvā́ri || cátasra |- ! Instrumental | colspan="2"| tribhíh | tisṛ́bhih | colspan="2"| catúrbhih | catasṛ́bhih |- ! Dative | colspan="2"| tribhyáh | tisṛ́bhyah | colspan="2"| catúrbhyah | catasṛ́bhyah |- ! Ablative | colspan="2"| tribhyáh | tisṛ́bhyah | colspan="2"| catúrbhyah | catasṛ́bhyah |- ! Genitive | colspan="2"|triyāṇā́m | tisṛṇā́m | colspan="2"| caturṇā́m | catasṛṇā́m |- ! Locative | colspan="2"| triṣú | tisṛ́ṣu | colspan="2"| catúrṣu | catasṛ́ṣu |} ==Personal pronouns and determiners== {{Main|Sanskrit pronouns and determiners}} Sanskrit [[pronouns]] are declined for [[grammatical case|case]], [[grammatical number|number]], and gender. Many pronouns have alternative [[enclitic]] forms. The first and second [[Grammatical person|person]] pronouns are declined for the most part alike, having by [[analogy]] assimilated themselves with one another. [[Ablative]]s in singular and plural may be extended by the syllable -''tas''; thus ''mat'' or ''mattas'', ''asmat'' or ''asmattas''. Sanskrit does not have true third person pronouns, but its demonstratives fulfil this function instead by standing independently without a modified [[substantive]]. There are four different [[demonstrative]]s in Sanskrit: ''tat'', ''etat'', ''idam'', and ''adas''. ''etat'' indicates greater proximity than ''tat''. While ''idam'' is similar to ''etat'', ''adas'' refers to objects that are more remote than ''tat''. ''eta'', is declined almost identically to ''ta''. Its paradigm is obtained by prefixing ''e-'' to all the forms of ''ta''. As a result of ''[[sandhi]]'', the masculine and feminine singular forms transform into ''{{IAST|eṣas}}'' and ''{{IAST|eṣã}}''. The enclitic pronoun ''ena'' is found only in a few [[oblique case]]s and numbers. [[Interrogative pronoun]]s all begin with ''k-'', and decline just as ''tat'' does, with the initial ''t-'' being replaced by ''k-''. The only exception to this are the singular neuter [[nominative]] and [[accusative]] forms, which are both ''kim'' and not the expected ''*kat''. For example, the singular feminine [[genitive]] interrogative pronoun, "of whom?", is ''{{IAST|kasyãḥ}}''. [[Indefinite pronoun]]s are formed by adding the participles ''api'', ''cid'', or ''cana'' after the appropriate interrogative pronouns. All [[relative pronoun]]s begin with ''y-'', and decline just as ''tat'' does. The [[correlative pronoun]]s are identical to the ''tat'' series. In addition to the pronouns described above, some [[adjective]]s follow the pronominal declension. Unless otherwise noted, their declension is identical to ''tat''. * ''eka'': "one", "a certain". (singular neuter nominative and accusative forms are both ''ekam'') * ''anya'': "another". * ''sarva'': "all", "every". (singular neuter nominative and accusative forms are both ''sarvam'') * ''para'': "the other". (singular neuter nominative and accusative forms are both ''param'') * ''sva'': "self" (a reflexive adjective). (singular neuter nominative and accusative forms are both ''svam'') ==Compounds== {{Main|Sanskrit compounds}} One other notable feature of the nominal system is the very common use of nominal compounds, which in the later literary language may be huge (10+ words) as in some modern languages such as [[German language|German]] and [[Finnish language|Finnish]]. Nominal compounds occur with various structures, however morphologically speaking they are essentially the same. Each noun (or adjective) is in its (weak) stem form, with only the final element receiving case inflection. The four principle categories of nominal compounds are:{{cite book|last1=Warnemyr|first1=Lennart|title=An analytical cross referenced Sanskrit Grammar|url=http://www.warnemyr.com/skrgram/}} * [[Dvandva]] (co-ordinative) : These consist of two or more [[noun]] stems, connected in sense with 'and'. Examples are ''rāma-lakşmaņau''—Rama and Lakshmana, ''rāma-lakşmaņa-bharata-śatrughnāh''—Rama, Lakshmana, Bharata and Satrughna, and ''pāņipādam''—limbs, literally hands and feet, from pāņi = hand and pāda = foot. * [[Tatpurusha|Tatpuruṣa]] (determinative) : There are many tatpuruṣas; in a tatpuruṣa the first component is in a case relationship with another. For example, a doghouse is a dative compound, a house ''for'' a dog; other examples include instrumental relationships ("thunderstruck") and locative relationships ("towndwelling"). * [[Karmadhāraya]] (descriptive) : A compound where the relation of the first member to the last is [[apposition]]al, [[Substantive adjective|attributive]] or [[adverbial]]; e.g., uluka-yatu (owl+demon) is a demon in the shape of an owl. Karmadhārayas are considered by some to be tatpuruṣas. * [[Bahuvrīhi]] (possessive/exocentric) : Bahuvrīhi compounds refer to a compound noun that refers to a thing which is itself not part of the compound. For example the word bahuvrīhi itself, from bahu = much and vrīhi = rice, denotes a rich person—one who has much rice. == Phonology == {{Further|Śikṣā}} Classical Sanskrit distinguishes about 36 [[phoneme]]s. There is, however, some [[allophone|allophony]] and the writing systems used for Sanskrit generally indicate this, thus distinguishing 48 [[Phone (phonetics)|sounds]]. The sounds are traditionally listed in the order [[vowel]]s (''Ac''), [[diphthong]]s (''Hal''), [[anusvara]] and [[visarga]], [[Plosive consonant|plosives]] (Sparśa) and [[nasal stop|nasals]] (starting in the back of the mouth and moving forward), and finally the [[liquid consonants|liquids]] and [[fricative]]s, written in [[IAST]] as follows: {| class="wikitable" |+Classification of Sanskrit phonemes and allophones indicated in writing - IAST Romanisation !Type !Classification !Phonemes |- ! rowspan="4" |Vowels !Plain |a ā i ī u ū |- !Syllabic | ṛ ṝ ḷ ḹ |- !Diphthongs |e ai o au |- !Semivowels |y |- ! rowspan="6" |Consonants !Anusvara |ṃ |- !Visarga |{{IAST| ḥ}} |- !Plosives |k kh g gh ṭ ṭh ḍ ḍh t th d dh p ph b bh |- !Nasals |ṅ ñ ṇ n m |- !Liquids |r l |- !Fricatives and affricates |v ś ṣ s h c ch j jh |} : An alternate traditional ordering is that of the [[Shiva Sutra]] of {{IAST|[[Pāṇini]]}}. It should be understood that, while the script used here is [[Devanagari]], this has no particular importance. It just happens currently to be the most popular script for Sanskrit. The form of the symbols used to write Sanskrit has varied widely geographically and over time, and notably includes in modern times the Tamil and other modern Indian scripts. What is important is that the adherence to the phonological classification of the symbols elucidated here has remained constant in Sanskrit since classical times. It should be further noted that the phonology of modern Indian languages has evolved, and the values given to Devanagari symbols in, e.g. Hindi, differ somewhat from those of Sanskrit. === Vowels === Further information: [[:File:The_International_Phonetic_Alphabet_(revised_to_2015).pdf|IPA chart (vowels and consonants) - 2015.]] and [[IPA vowel chart with audio]] {{spoken}} The vowels of Classical Sanskrit written in [[Devanagari]], as a syllable-initial letter and as a [[diacritic]] mark on the [[consonant]] {{lang-sa2|प्}} ({{IPA|/p/}}), pronunciation transcribed in [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]], [[IAST]], and approximate equivalent in English: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Letter !! {{lang-sa2|प्}} !! IPA !! [[IAST]] !! |- | {{lang-sa2|अ}} || {{lang-sa2|प}} || {{IPA|[ə]}} || a || Although, as a more closed vowel, it markedly differs in quality from ''{{IAST|ā}}'', phonologically it functions as its short counterpart.{{sfn|Allen|1953|p=58}} |- | {{lang-sa2|आ}} || {{lang-sa2|पा}} || {{IPA|[ɑː]}} || ā || |- | {{lang-sa2|इ}} || {{lang-sa2|पि}} || {{IPA|[i]}} || i || |- | {{lang-sa2|ई}} || {{lang-sa2|पी}} || {{IPA|[iː]}} || ī || |- | {{lang-sa2|उ}} || {{lang-sa2|पु}} || {{IPA|[u]}} || u || |- | {{lang-sa2|ऊ}} || {{lang-sa2|पू}} || {{IPA|[uː]}} || ū || |- | {{lang-sa2|ऋ}} || {{lang-sa2|पृ}} || {{IPA|[r̩]}} || ṛ || syllabic [[alveolar trill]]: closest to ''er'' in butt'''er''' in rhotic accents |- | {{lang-sa2|ॠ}} || {{lang-sa2|पॄ}} || {{IPA|[r̩ː]}} || ṝ || syllabic [[alveolar trill]]: closest to ''ir'' in b'''ir'''d in rhotic accents |- | {{lang-sa2|ऌ}} || {{lang-sa2|पॢ}} || {{IPA|[l̩]}} || ḷ || syllabic [[dental lateral approximant]]: ''le'' in turt'''le''' |- | {{lang-sa2|ॡ}} || {{lang-sa2|पॣ}} || {{IPA|[l̩ː]}} || ḹ || syllabic [[dental lateral approximant]]: longer ''le'' |- | {{lang-sa2|ए}} || {{lang-sa2|पे}} || {{IPA|[e]}} || e || long [[close-mid front unrounded vowel]]: ''a'' in b'''a'''ne (some speakers) |- | {{lang-sa2|ऐ}} || {{lang-sa2|पै}} || [əi] || ai || a [[diphthong]]: ''i'' in '''i'''ce, ''i'' in k'''i'''te (US, [[Canadian English|Canadian]], and [[Scottish English]]) |- | {{lang-sa2|ओ}} || {{lang-sa2|पो}} || {{IPA|[o]}} || o || [[close-mid back rounded vowel]]: ''o'' in b'''o'''ne ([[Scottish English]]) |- | {{lang-sa2|औ}} || {{lang-sa2|पौ}} || [əu] || au || a [[diphthong]]: ''ou'' in h''ou''se (Canadian English) |} The [[vowel length|long vowels]] are pronounced twice as long as their short counterparts. Also, there exists a third, extra-long length for most vowels. This lengthening is called ''[[pluti]]''; the lengthened vowels, called ''pluta'', are used in various cases, but particularly in the [[vocative]]. The ''pluti'' is not accepted by all grammarians. The vowels {{IPA|/e/}} and {{IPA|/o/}} continue as allophonic variants of [[Proto-Indo-Iranian]] {{IPA|/ai/}}, {{IPA|/au/}} and are categorised as diphthongs by Sanskrit grammarians even though they are realised phonetically as simple long vowels. Additional points: * There are some additional signs traditionally listed in tables of the [[Devanagari]] script: ** The diacritic {{lang-sa2|ं}} called ''anusvāra'', ([[IAST]]: ''{{IAST|ṃ}}''). It is a ''pure'' voiced ''nasal'' sound having no oral or oro-nasal articulation.{{Cite web|url = http://www.sanskritweb.net/sansdocs/anusvara.pdf|title = A MONOGRAPH ON THE ANUSVĀRA OF THE TAITTIRĪYA KṚṢṆA YAJUR VEDA|date = |accessdate = |website = http://www.sanskritweb.net/|publisher = |last = Sharma|first = Shriramana}}{{Clarify|date=February 2017}} {{xref|(See also {{slink|Anusvara|Sanskrit}})}} ** The diacritic {{lang-sa2|ः}} called ''[[visarga]]'', represents voiceless glottal fricative (IPA: [h]) whose voiced counterpart is the consonant ''{{IAST|h}}'' {{IPA|[ɦ]}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2009/09372-grantha.pdf|title=Proposal to encode the Grantha script in Unicode|last=Sharma|first=Shriramana|date=2009-10-24|website=https://www.unicode.org/|publisher=|page=40|access-date=December 12, 2016}} ** The diacritic {{lang-sa2|ँ}} called ''[[candrabindu]]'' indicates the nasalization of a vowel or the semi-vowels y,v,l{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2010/10392r2-chandrabindus.pdf|title=Request to encode South Indian CANDRABINDU-s|last=Sharma,|first=Shriramana|date=2010-10-11|website=https://www.unicode.org/|publisher=|access-date=12 December 2016}} * If a lone consonant needs to be written without any following vowel, it is given a ''virāma'' (or ''[[halanta]]'') diacritic below ({{lang-sa2|प्}}). * The vowel {{IPA|/aː/}} in Sanskrit is realised as being more central and less back than the closest English approximation, which is {{IPA|/ɑː/}}. But the grammarians have classified it as a back vowel.{{cite book|last=Maurer|first=Walter|title=The sanskrit language : an introductory grammar and reader|publisher=Curzon|location=Surrey, England|year=2001|isbn=0-7007-1382-4}} * The ancient Sanskrit grammarians classified the vowels as [[velar]]s, [[retroflex]]es, [[palatal]]s and [[plosive]]s rather than as back, central and front vowels. Hence {{lang-sa2|ए}} and {{lang-sa2|ओ}} are classified respectively as palato-velar (a+i) and labio-velar (a+u) vowels respectively. But the grammarians have classified them as [[diphthong]]s and in prosody, each is given two ''mātrās''. This does not necessarily mean that they are proper diphthongs, but neither excludes the possibility that they could have been proper diphthongs at a very ancient stage. These vowels are pronounced as long {{IPA|/eː/}} and {{IPA|/oː/}} respectively by priests of today. Other than the "four" diphthongs, Sanskrit usually disallows any other diphthong—vowels in succession, where they occur, are converted to [[semivowel]]s according to [[sandhi]] rules. * The vowels {{IPA|[r̩]}} and {{IPA|[r̩ː]}} were [[syllabic r]]hotics,{{sfn|Allen|1953|p=53, Allen describes this as the "vowel ṛ", a terminology that is now unfashionable, the difference being that the modern term avoids the use of the concept "vowel"}} much the same as in English "butter" and the Hindi "patr", meaning letter. Indian descendant languages of Sanskrit lost the vocalic r, and Indian pandits came to pronounce it as variously "ri" in the North - as in the name of the god known there as "krishn" -, "ru" in the West - where the same god is commonly referred to as "krushna" -, and "ra" in the East. When vocalic r reappeared in modern Indian languages due to the loss of final "a" in Sanskrit loan words such as "patra" > "patr" in Hindi (ending in a vocalic r rather than short a, in accordance with Hindi phonology), replacing Prakrit and Apabramsha "patta" - the natural derivative of the Sanskrit - it was not recognised by modern speakers that this corresponded to the vocalic r of ancient Sanskrit. === Consonants === Further information: [[:File:The_International_Phonetic_Alphabet_(revised_to_2015).pdf|IPA chart (vowels and consonants) - 2015.]] and [[IPA pulmonic consonant chart with audio]] {{spoken}} [[IAST]] and [[Devanagari]] notations are given, with approximate [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] values in square brackets.{{cite book|last=Stiehl|first=Ulrich|title=Sanskrit-Kompendium : ein Lehr-, Übungs- und Nachschlagewerk; Devanagari-Ausgabe|publisher=Forkel|location=Heidelberg|year=2011|isbn=978-3-7719-0086-1|language=de|url=http://www.sanskritweb.net/deutsch/ipa_sans.pdf}} {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan="2"| !colspan="2"| [[Labial consonant|Labial]]

{{IPA|/ɦə/}}; English a'''h'''ead |} In the earlier language, {{lang-sa2|व}} was pronounced as the [[labio-velar approximant]] {{IPA|[w]}}, but it later developed into a [[labio-dental]] sound.{{sfn|Allen|1953|p=57}} To an English speaker's ear, this sound may be interpreted as the English "v" or the English "w", depending on context and precise articulation. Moreover, the Sanskrit व has a considerable range of articulation depending on position. .{{sfn|Allen|1953|p=28,58}} It is nonetheless understood in the Sanskrit writing system, as well as by speakers of modern Indian languages, as one and the same phoneme. === Accent === {{main|Vedic accent}} Vedic Sanskrit has [[pitch accent]]; some syllables have a high tone, and the following syllable is a falling tone, though through ellipsis a falling tone may occur elsewhere. === Phonology and sandhi === The Sanskrit vowels are as discussed in the section above. The long syllabic l (ḹ) is not attested, and is only discussed by grammarians for systematic reasons. Its short counterpart ḷ occurs in a single root only, kḷp "to order, array". Long syllabic r (ṝ) is also quite marginal, occurring in the genitive plural of r-stems (e.g. ''mātṛ'' "mother" and ''pitṛ'' "father" have gen.pl. ''mātṝṇām'' and ''pitṝṇām''). i, u, ṛ, ḷ are vocalic allophones of consonantal y, v, r, l. There are thus only 5 invariably vocalic [[phoneme]]s: a, ā, ī, ū, ṝ. [[Visarga]] ḥ {{lang-sa2|ः}} is an [[allophone]] of r and s, and [[anusvara]] ṃ, [[Devanagari]] {{lang-sa2| ं}} of any nasal, both in [[pausa]] (i.e., the [[nasalized vowel|nasalised vowel]]). The exact pronunciation of the three sibilants may vary, but they are distinct phonemes. Voiced sibilants, such as z {{IPA|/z/}}, ẓ {{IPA|/ʐ/}}, and ź {{IPA|/ʑ/}} as well as its aspirated counterpart źh {{IPA|/ʑʱ/}}, were inherited by [[Proto-Indo-Aryan language|Proto-Indo-Aryan]] from Proto-Indo-Iranian but lost around or after the time of the [[Rigveda]], as evidenced due to ḷh (an aspirated retroflex lateral consonant) being metrically a cluster (that was most likely of the form ẓḍh; aspirated fricatives are exceedingly rare in any language). The [[retroflex consonant]]s are somewhat marginal phonemes, often being conditioned by their phonetic environment; they do not continue a [[PIE]] series and are often ascribed by some linguists to the [[substratum|substratal]] influence of [[Dravidian languages|Dravidian]]{{cite web|url= http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_go2081/is_/ai_n28679333|title= On the Indo-European origins of the retroflexes in Sanskrit|accessdate = 8 January 2009| author=Hamp, Eric P.|date = October–December 1996| publisher = The Journal of the American Oriental Society}} or other substrate languages. The nasal {{IPA|[ɲ]}} is a conditioned allophone of {{IPA|/n/}} ({{IPA|/n/}} and {{IPA|/ɳ/}} are distinct phonemes—aṇu 'minute', 'atomic' [nom. sg. neutr. of an adjective] is distinctive from anu 'after', 'along'; phonologically independent /ŋ/ occurs only marginally, e.g. in prāṅ 'directed forwards/towards' [nom. sg. masc. of an adjective]). There are thus 31 consonantal or semi-vocalic phonemes, consisting of four/five kinds of stops realised both with or without aspiration and both voiced and voiceless, three nasals, four semi-vowels or liquids, and four fricatives, written in [[IAST]] transliteration as follows: k, kh, g, gh; c, ch, j, jh; ṭ, ṭh, ḍ, ḍh; t, th, d, dh; p, ph, b, bh; m, n, ṇ; y, r, l, v; ś, ṣ, s, h or a total of 36 unique Sanskrit phonemes altogether. The [[phonology|phonological]] rules which are applied when combining morphemes to a word, and when combining words to a sentence, are collectively called ''[[sandhi]]'' "composition". Texts are written phonetically, with sandhi applied (except for the so-called ''padapāṭha''). === Phonological processes === '''{{vanchor|Abhinidhāna|Abhinidhana}}''' (lit. 'adjacent imposition'), (also known as ''{{IAST|āsthāpita}}'', 'stoppage', ''{{IAST|bhakṣya}}'' or ''{{IAST|bhukta}}'') is the [[No audible release|incomplete articulation]], or ""represssing or obscuring", of a [[plosive]] or, according to some texts, a [[semi-vowel]] (except r), which occurs before another plosive or a pause.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|p=137}} It was described in the various [[Prātiśākhya]]s as well as the ''{{IAST|Cārāyaṇīya Śikṣa}}''.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|p=137}} These texts are not unanimous on the [[Phonetic environment|environments]] that trigger abhinidhana, nor on the precise classes of consonants affected. One ancient grammarian, ''{{IAST|Vyāḍi}}'' (in {{IAST|Ṛgveda Prātiśākhya}} 6.12), states that {{IAST|abhinidhāna}} only occurred when a consonant was [[Consonant gemination|doubled]], whereas according to the text of the ''{{IAST|Śākalas}}'' it was obligatory in this context but optional for plosives before another plosive of a different [[place of articulation]]. The ''{{IAST|Śākalas}}'' and the ''{{IAST|Atharva Veda Prātiśākhya}}'' agree on the observation that abhinidhana occurs only if there is a slight pause between the two consonants and not if they are pronounced jointly.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|p=138}} Word-finally, plosives undergo abhinidhāna according to the {{IAST|Atharva Veda Prātiśākhya}} and the ''{{IAST|Ṛgveda Prātiśākhya}}''. The latter text adds that final semivowels (excluding r) are also incompletely articulated.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|p=140}} The ''{{IAST|Atharva Veda Prātiśākhya}}'' 2.38 lists an exception: a plosive at the end of the word will not undergo {{IAST|abhinidhāna}} and will be fully released if it is followed by a consonant whose place of articulation is further back in the mouth.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|pp=141–2}} The ''{{IAST|Cārāyaṇīya Śikṣa}}'' states that the consonants affected by abhinidhāna are the voiceless unaspirated plosives, the nasal consonants and the semivowels ''{{IAST|l}}'' and ''{{IAST|v}}''.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|p=142}} According to Siddheshwar Varma, these differences may indicate geographical variation.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|p=139}} It is not clear whether abhinidhana was present in the early spoken Sanskrit or it developed at a later stage.{{Sfn|Varma|1961|pp=137–8}} In [[Prakrit]] and [[Pāli]] abhinidhana was carried a step forward into complete [[Assimilation (linguistics)|assimilation]], as for example {{lang-sa|sapta}} to {{lang-pka|satta}}. == Syntax == Because of Sanskrit's complex [[declension]] system, the [[word order]] is free.{{cite book|author=J.F. Staal|title=Word Order in Sanskrit and Universal Grammar|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VqihQhNkqu4C&pg=PA28|date=31 January 1967|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-90-277-0549-5}} In usage, there is a strong tendency toward [[subject–object–verb|subject – object – verb (SOV)]], which was the original system in place in Vedic prose. However, there are exceptions when word pairs cannot be transposed.{{citation | last=Gillon|first=B.S | date= 25 March 1996 | journal=Indian linguistics | issn=0378-0759 |volume=57 | title=Word order in Classical Sanskrit | url=http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=2875140 |issue=1 – 4 | page=1}} == Peculiar characteristics == In the introduction to his celebrated translation of [[Vidyakara]]'s 'Subhashitaratnakosha', [[Daniel H. H. Ingalls, Sr.|Daniel H.H. Ingalls]] describes some peculiar characteristics of the Sanskrit language. He refers to the enormous vocabulary of Sanskrit, and also of the presence of a larger choice of synonyms in Sanskrit than any other language he knew of. Further, he writes, just as there exist a vast number of synonyms for almost any word in Sanskrit, there also exist synonymous constructions. Ingalls writes that in elementary Sanskrit examinations he would ask his students to write in Sanskrit the sentence 'You must fetch the horse' in ten different ways. Actually, Ingalls explains, it is possible to write the sentence in Sanskrit in around fifteen different ways 'by using active or passive constructions, imperative or optative, an auxiliary verb, or any of the three gerundive forms, each of which, by the way, gives a different metrical pattern'. Ingalls emphasizes that while these constructions differ formally, emotionally they are identical and completely interchangeable. He comments that in any natural language this would be impossible. Ingalls uses this and other arguments to show that Sanskrit is not a natural language, but an 'artificial' language. By 'artificial', he explains he means it was learned after some other Indian language had been learned by simple conditioning. Ingalls writes: 'Every Indian, one may suppose, grew up learning naturally the language of his mother and his playmates. Only after this and if he belonged to the priesthood or the nobility or to such a professional caste as that of the clerks, the physicians, or the astrologers would he learn Sanskrit. As a general rule, Sanskrit was not the language of the family. It furnished no subconscious symbols for the impressions which we receive in childhood nor for the emotions which form our character in early adolescence.'{{cite book|author=Vidyākara|title=An anthology of Sanskrit court poetry; Vidyākara's|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge|year=1965|isbn=978-0-674-03950-6|pages=5–8}} ==See also== * [[Catur sloki]] * [[Sanskrit pronouns and determiners]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{Citation|last= Allen| first= W.S.| title= Phonetics in ancient India| year= 1953| publisher= OUP}} * B. Delbrück, ''Altindische Tempuslehre'' (1876) [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN1421246880&id=_-9K_xT8OBAC&dq=Altindische] Topics in Sanskrit morphology and syntax * [[Frits Staal]], ''Word order in Sanskrit and Universal Grammar'', Foundations of Language, supplementary series 5, Springer (1967), {{ISBN|978-90-277-0549-5}}. *{{Cite book| publisher = Munshi Ram Manohar Lal| last = Varma| first = Siddheshwar| title = Critical studies in the phonetic observations of Indian grammarians.| location = Delhi| series = James G. Forlong Fund| date = 1961| orig-year = 1927| ref = harv}} * Wackernagel, Debrunner, ''[[Altindische Grammatik]]'', Göttingen. ** vol. I. phonology [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN1421247127&id=mWaIUMIoUvkC&dq=Altindische] [[Jacob Wackernagel]] (1896) ** vol. II.1. introduction to morphology, nominal composition, Wackernagel (1905) [https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN1421247100&id=qql6RRqTAuIC&dq=Altindische] ** vol. II.2. nominal suffixes, J. Wackernagel and [[Albert Debrunner]] (1954) ** vol. III. nominal inflection, numerals, pronouns, Wackernagel and Debrunner (1930) * W. D. Whitney, ''Sanskrit Grammar: Including both the Classical Language and the Older Dialects'' * W. D. Whitney, ''The Roots, Verb-Forms and Primary Derivatives of the Sanskrit Language (A Supplement to His Sanskrit Grammar)'' == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111010034042/http://vedicsociety.org/sanskrit/sandhi/ Vedic Society Sandhi Calculator] * [http://flaez.ch/cgi-bin/sandhi.pl Online tool to perform and undo Sanskrit sandhi effects]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://littleredbook.vedicsociety.org.in/ Little Red Book] * [http://indologiaitalia.blogspot.it/p/grammatiche-di-sanscrito-sanskrit.html Sanskrit grammars] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130115171411/http://www.shastranethralaya.org/LectureOthers.html Sanskrit grammar Laghu-Siddanta-Kaumudi (English & Tamil Lectures)] * [https://www.youtube.com/shastralayam Sanskrit grammar Video AdiLaghu (English & Tamil)] {{Sanskrit language topics}} {{Indo-Aryan grammars}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sanskrit Grammar}} [[Category:Sanskrit grammar| ]] [[Category:Grammars of specific languages]]

{{multiple image | width = 180 | footer = ''Two shot groupings obtained with different firearms at different distances.''
'''The group on the left''' measures about 13 mm and was fired at about 45 meters, which equals {{sfrac|13 mm|45 m}} = 0.29 mils (''{{frac|1|2}} in group at 50 yards, approx. 1.047′×{{sfrac|50|100}} = 0.524′'').
'''The group on the right''' measures about 7 mm and was fired at about 90 meters, which equals {{sfrac|7 mm|90 m}} = 0.08 mils (''0.3 in group at 100 yards, approx. 1.047′×0.3 = 0.314′''). | image1 = Target 22mag Striker.jpg | image2 = Target 223 Savage 10FP 5 shot.jpg }} In [[shooting sports]], a '''shot grouping''', or simply '''group''', is the pattern of [[projectile]] impacts on a [[shooting target|target]] from multiple shots taken in one shooting session. The tightness of the grouping (the proximity of all the shots to each other) is a measure of the [[accuracy and precision|precision]] of a weapon, and a measure of the shooter's consistency and skill.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t5TKeLd6sw4C&pg=PA65 |pages=65–6 |title=Do-it-yourself Gun Repair: Gunsmithing at Home |last=Matunas |first=Edward |publisher=Woods N' Water |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-9722804-2-6}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IUwFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA196 |pages=196–8 |title=ABCs of Rifle Shooting |last=Watson |first=David |publisher=F+W Media |year=2014 |isbn=978-1-4402-3897-0}} On the other hand, the grouping displacement (the distance between the calculated group center and the intended point of aim) is a measure of [[accuracy]]. Tightness of shot groupings are calculated by measuring the distance between bullet holes on the target (center-to-center) in length measurements such as [[millimeter]]s or [[inch]]es. Often that measurement is converted into [[Angular unit|angular measurements]], such as [[milliradian]]s (mils) or [[minutes of angle]] (MOAs), which expresses the size of shot spreads regardless of the target distance. Thus, by using angular measurements, one can reliably compare the relative tightness of shot groupings fired at different distances. == Uses of the term == For [[firearm]]s that shoot one round at a time, a shot grouping test can be used to measure the accuracy of the entire shooting system: the weapon's mechanical precision and the uniformity of the ammunition. The weapon is fixed into position on a test mount, and aimed at a target. Multiple shots using rounds from the same type and batch are fired to observe how the weapon groups the shots. If a person holds the weapon and shoots it, the grouping measures the combination of the person's skill and the weapon's accuracy. In [[shotgun]] shooting, the grouping is also called the ''pattern''. The pattern is the spread of [[shot (pellet)|shot]]s from a single [[shotshell]], measured as the smallest circle containing all the shots on the target. The barrel of a shotgun is designed to deliver a wide or narrow scattering, depending on the expected use. Shooting at close range indicates a cylinder bore barrel to deliver a wide grouping, while for hunting at longer distances such as 50 yards or meters, a [[choke (firearm)|choke]] is recommended for to constrict the scattering for a tighter grouping.{{cite web |url=http://www.briley.com/understandingshotgunchokesabriefexplanationbybriley.aspx |title=Understanding Shotgun Chokes, A brief explanation by Briley |first=Cliff |last=Moller |publisher=Briley Manufacturing |accessdate=August 10, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150729172417/http://www.briley.com/understandingshotgunchokesabriefexplanationbybriley.aspx |archivedate=July 29, 2015 |df= }} In [[archery]], a shot grouping is the result of one person shooting multiple arrows at a target. A tight grouping indicates consistency in the archer's [[form (exercise)|form]]. == Firearms == [[File:Mil sight adjustment.png|thumb|right|Diagram illustrating the relationship between distance, group size on the target (subtension) and angular group size.]] Mean point of impact (MPI) is the calculated center of the grouping, which is the average center of all the shots, and is not necessarily located at a hole in the target. The process of mechanically readjusting the [[gunsight]]’s point of aim to match the MPI is called [[sighting in]] or “zeroing” the aim. The size of the grouping is described as the diameter of the smallest circle that can be drawn to contain all the shots.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Bdy7mT4iWMgC&pg=PA97 |page=87 |title=A to Z Guide to White-tailed Deer and Deer Hunting |last=Gilbert |first=Randall |publisher=Woods N' Water |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-9707493-9-0}} A "flier" is a shot from the same shooting session that is farther from the general grouping, considered to be the [[outlier]] of the group. Such shots may be the result of an unexpected gust of wind causing drifting, a muscular flinch of the shooter at the time of the trigger pull, a problem with the firearm mechanism, or inconsistency in the ammunition.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wwktAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT174 |pages=172–75 |title=The Self-Reliance Manifesto: Essential Outdoor Survival Skills |first=Len |last=McDougall |publisher=Skyhorse |year=2013 |isbn=9781628733006}} Single fliers may be discounted when evaluating large groupings, but if fliers occur often, then the problem should be traced to its origin. While target shooting with a [[handgun]], if a grouping is consistently off-center then the shooter is instructed to alter the body angle or the stance, rather than shifting the arm, wrist or hand, which should remain in position.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mQ2ObSfrWSoC&pg=PA214 |page=214 |title=Ed McGivern's Book of Fast and Fancy Revolver Shooting |last=McGivern |first=Ed |publisher=Skyhorse Publishing |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-60239-086-7}} === Metric units === When using [[International System of Units|SI units]], shooting accuracy is more easily measured in [[milliradian]]s by measuring the group size in millimeters (or in centimeters and multiplying by a factor of 10) and dividing by the range measured in meters. :\text{group size in mils} = \frac{\text{group size in mm}}{\text{range in m}} = \frac{\text{group size in cm}}{\text{range in m}} \times 10 Since shot grouping are small angles, the linear formula above can be used as a good approximation for group sizes in mils. The error of assuming that 0.1 mil equals 1 cm at 100 meters is about 1 × 10{{sup|-7}} (or 0.00001 %). === Imperial units === When using [[imperial units]], shooting accuracy is more easily measured in [[minutes of arc]] (symbol ′, sometimes called "minutes of angle" or "MOA" for short) by measuring the group size in inches, multiplying by a factor of 100 and dividing by the range measured in yards. :\text{group size in arcminutes} \approx \frac{\text{group size in inches}}{\text{range in yd}} \times 100 \times 1.04717593 \approx \frac{\text{group size in inches}}{\text{range in yd}} \times 100 The linear formula above for measuring group sizes in arcminutes is less precise than using milliradians together with metric units, but can still be a good approximation depending on the demands for precision. The error of assuming that 1′ equals 1" at 100 yd is about 4.5 %. When shooting at a target 100 yards away, 1′ is a circle of approximately 1.047 inches in diameter,[http://dexadine.com/WhatMOA.htm Dexadine Ballistics Software - ballistic data for shooting and reloading] while at 100 meters, 1′ is approximately a 29.1 millimeter circle. The arcminute is an [[Minute and second of arc|arc-based measurement]], with 1′ equal to one minute of one degree. The two-dimensional circle surrounding a shooter always has 21,600 arcminutes because there are 60 minutes in each degree, and 360 degrees in the circle. === Benchmarks === A [[big-game hunting]] [[rifle]] is considered accurate if its shots fall within 1.5′ (≈ 0.5 mil), while a rifle intended for small animals is expected to have an accuracy of 1′ or less (under 0.3 mil, also known as "sub-MOA"). [[Handgun]]s are typically less accurate; at a shooting distance of 25 yd, a grouping is considered acceptable for [[self-defense]] if the shots fall within a circle of 4 to 5 inches, which is 15′ to 19′ (equivalent to a grouping of 100-150 mm at 25 meters, which is 4-6 mils),{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L9rHbdm6xDoC&pg=PA31 |page=31 |title=The Gun Digest Book of Personal Protection & Home Defense |last=Campbell |first=Robert K. |publisher=Krause Publications |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-89689-938-4}}, representing the shot pattern needed to hit the vital organs of a human target. Expensive and well-machined [[match-grade]] pistols demonstrate a higher accuracy than normal handguns, capable of groupings of 1.25 inches at 25 yards, which is about 5′ (equivalent to about 30 mm at 25 meters, which is 1.2 mil).{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u8wX1IVbBWYC&pg=PA87 |page=87 |title=The Gun Digest Book of Tactical Gear |first=Dan |last=Shideler |first2=Derrek |last2=Sigler |first3=Ken |last3=Ramage |publisher=Gun Digest Books |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-89689-684-0}} == Archery == With the increased element of human skill in archery, a grouping on target is more a measure of the archer's skill. If an archer is not getting a consistent grouping, then their basic form needs work. If an archer's [[arrow]]s are grouping on target but off center, this shows consistent basic form, with better results achievable after slight adjustments.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QHEnFz1m_JQC&pg=PA72 |pages=72–3, 86 |title=Archery Fundamentals |last=Engh |first=Douglas |publisher=Human Kinetics |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-7360-5501-7}}{{cite book |page=42 |title=Archery: Steps to Success |edition=4 |last=Haywood |first=Kathleen |last2=Lewis |first2=Catherine |publisher=Human Kinetics |year=2013 |isbn=978-1-4504-4468-2}} On the equipment side, bow stabilizers have been used since the 1960s by tournament competitors and by bow hunters to counteract the torque of shooting the arrow. A tighter grouping may be achieved with such a stabilizer, which adds mass extending outward on a [[Moment (physics)|moment arm]], usually mounted perpendicular to the bow riser, aligned with the arrow path.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zQAtAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT293 |page=293 |title=The Traditional Bowyers Encyclopedia |last=Bertalan |first=Dan |publisher=Skyhorse Publishing |year=2013 |isbn=978-1-62873-012-8}}Haywood and Lewis 2013, p. 15.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UpE9ASq9F-QC&pg=PA131 |page=131 |title=Precision Archery |first=Steve |last=Ruis |first2=Claudia |last2=Stevenson |publisher=Human Kinetics |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-7360-4634-3}} == Example groupings == File:Nra-b3-targ-kimber-raptor.jpg|Handgun and paper target showing grouping of ten shots File:Offhandgroup25.jpg|A grouping made with a five-shot revolver File:Paper Target.jpg|Eight-shot grouping File:Glock31 220510.jpg|Multiple shots from a semi-automatic handgun File:Archery practice.jpeg|Arrow grouping with fairly consistent results but slightly off center == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Firearm shot grouping}} [[Category:Firearm terminology]] [[Category:Grouping]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Sjur Brækhus|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Sjur Brækhus''' (19 June 1918 – 19 May 2009) was a Norwegian legal scholar and judge.
He was born in [[Bergen]] as a son of captain and ship-owner Sigurd Alfred Brækhus (1879–1952) and Hilda Sverresdatter Klingenberg (1884–1957). He [[examen artium|finished]] his secondary education at [[Frogner School]] in 1936 and graduated with the [[cand.jur.]] degree at the [[University of Oslo]] in 1941. He was a deputy judge in [[Eiker, Modum and Sigdal District Court]] from 1941 to 1942. He became a [[research fellow]] at the University of Oslo in 1945 and took the [[dr.juris]] degree in 1947 with the thesis ''Meglerens rettslige stilling''. He was married twice, the first time from 1945 to 1957.<ref name=nbl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Sjur Brækhus|encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Birger Stuevold|last=Lassen|authorlink=Birger Stuevold Lassen|editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]]|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Sjur_Brækhus/utdypning|language=Norwegian|accessdate=25 December 2010}}</ref>
He was hired as a [[docent]] at the University of Oslo in 1947, and was promoted to professor already in 1948. He remained here until retirement in 1988. He served as [[dean (academic)|dean]] from 1963 to 1967. His main field was [[private law]] in general, and his main work was ''Omsetning og kreditt'', released in four volumes between 1985 and 1998. Sub-fields of note were [[maritime law]], [[bankruptcy law]] and court law.<ref name=nbl/> Other well-known books are ''Norsk tingsrett'' (1964 with Axel Hærem), ''Bergning'' (1968), ''Konkursrett'' (1969), and ''Sjørett, voldgift og lovvalg'' (1998). He edited the journal ''Arkiv for Sjørett'' from 1951 to 1970.<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=Sjur Brækhus|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=Henriksen, Petter|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/Sjur_Brækhus|language=Norwegian|accessdate=25 December 2010}}</ref>
He was also an acting presiding judge in [[Eidsivating Court of Appeal]] in 1953 as well as an arbitration court judge. He was a proponent for the Riksmål written form of the Norwegian language, and was a member of the [[Norwegian Language Council]] from 1976 to 1991 and the [[Norwegian Academy for Language and Literature]] from 1976 to his death.<ref name=nbl/>
He was a member of the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] from 1950 and held [[honorary degree]]s at the [[University of Copenhagen]] and [[Stockholm University]]. He was decorated as a Commander of the [[Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav]] in 1981,<ref name=nbl/> a Commander of the [[Order of the White Rose of Finland]] in 1990<ref>{{cite news|title=Høy finsk orden|date=12 October 1990|work=Aftenposten|page=10|language=Norwegian}}</ref> as well as a Knight of the [[Order of the Polar Star]].<ref name=nbl/>
He resided at [[Stabekk]].<ref name=ntb>{{cite news|title=Sjur Brækhus 80 år 19. juni|agency=Norwegian News Agency|date=12 June 1998|language=Norwegian}}</ref> He died in May 2009.<ref name=nbl/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{start box}} {{s-aca}} {{succession box |before=[[Johan Einarsen]] |title=[[dean (education)|Dean]] of the [[Faculty of Law, University of Oslo]] |years=1963–1967 |after=[[Johannes Andenæs]] }} {{end box}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Braekhus, Sjur}} [[Category:1918 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:People from Bergen]] [[Category:University of Oslo alumni]] [[Category:Academics of the Faculty of Law, University of Oslo]] [[Category:Norwegian judges]] [[Category:Norwegian legal scholars]] [[Category:Members of the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters]] [[Category:Knights of the Order of the Polar Star]] [[Category:Riksmål-language writers]]

{{Infobox software | name = Sketch Engine | title = | logo = Sketch Engine logo.svg | logo caption = Logo of Sketch Engine | logo size = 250px | logo alt = | screenshot = Concordance_in_Sketch_Engine.png | caption = Sketch Engine concordance page | screenshot size = | screenshot alt = | collapsible = | author = [[Adam Kilgarriff]], Pavel Rychlý | developer = Lexical Computing Ltd. | released = {{Start date and age|2003|07|23|df=yes}}<ref>[http://wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk/ Companies House] Searched on [[United Kingdom]]'s [[registrar of companies]] (Company name: LEXICAL COMPUTING LIMITED or Company number: 04841901)</ref> | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | status = Active | programming language = [[C++]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[JavaScript]], [[jQuery]] | operating system = [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]] | platform = [[IA-32]], [[x64]] or [[IA-64]] | size = | language = English, Czech, Chinese (Traditional, Simplified), Gaeilge, Slovene, Croatian, Arabic, Spanish, French, Ukrainian, Polish | language count = 12 | language footnote = | genre = [[Corpus manager]] for 90+ languages, [[database management systems|database management system]] | license = [[Proprietary software]]; both [[commercial software|commercial]] and [[freeware]] editions are available | alexa = | website = {{URL|www.sketchengine.co.uk}} | standard = [[Unicode]] | AsOf = }}
'''Sketch Engine''' is a corpus manager and [[text analysis]] software developed by Lexical Computing Limited since 2003. Its purpose is to enable people studying language behaviour ([[lexicographers]], researchers in [[corpus linguistics]], translators or language learners) to search large text collections according to complex and linguistically motivated queries. Sketch Engine gained its name after one of the key features, [[word sketch]]es: one-page, automatic, corpus-derived summaries of a word's grammatical and collocational behaviour.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kilgarriff|first1=Adam|last2=Baisa|first2=Vít|last3=Bušta|first3=Jan|last4=Jakubíček|first4=Miloš|last5=Kovář|first5=Vojtěch|last6=Michelfeit|first6=Jan|last7=Rychlý|first7=Pavel|last8=Suchomel|first8=Vít|title=The Sketch Engine: ten years on|journal=Lexicography|date=10 July 2014|volume=1|issue=1|pages=7–36|doi=10.1007/s40607-014-0009-9|issn=2197-4292|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40607-014-0009-9|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg}}</ref> Currently, it supports and provides corpora in 90+ languages.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/user-guide/user-manual/corpora/by-language/ |title= Languages in Sketch Engine |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Sketch Engine |publisher=Lexical Computing s.r.o. |access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>
== History of development == Sketch Engine is a product of Lexical Computing Limited, a company founded in 2003 by the lexicographer and research scientist [[Adam Kilgarriff]].<ref>[http://kilgarriff.co.uk Adam Kilgarriff's home page]</ref> He started collaboration with Pavel Rychlý, a computer scientist working at the Natural Language Processing Centre at [[Masaryk University]]<ref>[http://nlp.fi.muni.cz Natural Language Processing Centre, Masaryk University]</ref> and the developer of Manatee and Bonito (two major parts of the software suite), and introduced the concept of [[word sketch]]es.
Since then, Sketch Engine has been commercial software, however all the core features of Manatee and Bonito that were developed by 2003 (and extended since then) are freely available under the [[GPL]] license within the NoSketch Engine suite.<ref>[http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/trac/noske NoSketch Engine]</ref>
== Features == * [[Word sketch]]es – a one-page automatic derived summary of a word’s grammatical and collocational behaviour * Word sketch difference – compares and contrasts two words by analysing their collocation * Distributional [[Thesaurus]] – automated thesaurus finding words with similar meaning or appearing in the same/similar context * [[Concordance (publishing)|Concordance]] search – finds examples of a word form, lemma, phrase, tag or complex structure * [[Collocation]] search – word co-occurrence analysis displaying the most frequent words (to a search word) which can be regarded as collocation candidates * Word lists – generates frequency lists which can be filtered with complex criteria * [[n-gram]]s – generates frequency lists of multi-word expressions * [[Terminology extraction|Terminology]] / [[Keyword (linguistics)|Keyword]] extraction (both monolingual and bilingual) – automatic extraction key words and multi-word terms from texts (based on frequency count and linguistic criteria) * Diachronic analysis ([[Trend analysis|Trends]])<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kilgarriff|first1=Adam|last2=Herman|first2=Ondřej|last3=Bušta|first3=Jan|last4=Rychlý|first4=Pavel|last5=Jakubíček|first5=Miloš|title=DIACRAN: a framework for diachronic analysis|journal=Corpus Linguistics 2015|date=2015|pages=65–70|url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/Diacran_CL2015.pdf|publisher=Lancaster: UCREL}}</ref> – detecting words which undergo changes in the frequency of use in time (show trending words) * Corpus building and management – create corpora from the Web or uploaded texts including [[part-of-speech tagging]] and [[lemmatization]] which can be used as [[data mining]] software * [[Parallel corpus]] (bilingual) facilities – looking up translation examples (EUR-Lex corpus, [[Europarl corpus]], OPUS corpus, etc.) or building parallel corpus from own aligned texts
== Architecture == [[File:Thesaurus in Sketch Engine.png|thumb|upright=1.5|alt=Sketch Engine thesaurus page|Thesaurus cloud of the lemma ''work'' in Sketch Engine]]
Sketch Engine consists of three main components: an underlying [[database management system]] called Manatee, a web interface search front-end called Bonito and a web interface for corpus building and management called Corpus Architect. <ref name="bonito">{{cite journal|last1=Rychlý|first1=Pavel|title=Manatee/bonito–a modular corpus manager|journal=1st Workshop on Recent Advances in Slavonic Natural Language Processing|date=2007|pages=65–70|url=http://nlp.fi.muni.cz/raslan/2007/raslan07.pdf#page=73|publisher=Masaryk University}}</ref>
=== Manatee ===
Manatee is a [[database management system]] specifically devised for effective indexing of large text corpora. It is based on the idea of [[inverted index]]ing (keeping an index of all positions of a given word in the text). It has been used to index text corpora comprising tens of billions of words.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pomikálek|first1=Jan|last2=Jakubíček|first2=Miloš|last3=Rychlý|first3=Pavel|title=Building a 70 billion word corpus of English from ClueWeb|journal=Proceedings of the Eight International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation (LREC'12)|date=2012|url=http://www.lrec-conf.org/proceedings/lrec2012/pdf/1047_Paper.pdf|publisher=European Language Resources Association (ELRA)|location=Istanbul, Turkey}}</ref>
Searching corpora indexed by Manatee is performed by formulating queries in the Corpus Query Language (CQL).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/documentation/corpus-querying/ |title=CQL – Corpus Query Language |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Sketch Engine |publisher=Lexical Computing s.r.o. |access-date=22 January 2018}}</ref>
Manatee is written in [[C++]] and offers an [[API]] for a number of other programming languages including [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[Perl]] and [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]]. Recently, it was rewritten into [[Go (programming language)|Go]] for faster processing of corpus queries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rychlý|first1=Pavel|last2=Rábara|first2=Radoslav|title=Concurrent Processing of Text Corpus Queries|journal=Workshop on Recent Advances in Slavonic Natural Language Processing|date=2015|pages=49–58|url=https://www.sketchengine.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/Concurrent_Processing_2015.pdf|publisher=Masaryk University}}</ref>
=== Bonito ===
Bonito is a web interface for Manatee providing access to corpus search. In the [[client–server model]], Manatee is the server and Bonito plays the client part. It is written in [[Python (programming language)|Python]].<ref name="bonito" />
=== Corpus Architect ===
Corpus Architect is a web interface providing corpus building and management features. It is also written in [[Python (programming language)|Python]].
== Applications == Sketch Engine has been used by major British or other publishing houses for producing dictionaries such as [[Macmillan English Dictionary for Advanced Learners|Macmillan English Dictionary]], [[Dictionnaires Le Robert]], [[Oxford University Press]] or [[Shogakukan]] and four of the UK’s five biggest dictionary publishers use Sketch Engine.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://impact.ref.ac.uk/CaseStudies/CaseStudy.aspx?Id=39760 |title=Using Computational Lexicography for Dictionary Production with the Sketch Engine |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=REF Impact Case Studies |publisher=University of Brighton |access-date=18 April 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[SkELL]] – a free web service for students and teachers of English language based on Sketch Engine *[[TenTen Corpus Family]] – a multilingual set of comparable [[Web crawler|web corpora]] available through Sketch Engine
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{Cite book|url=http://www.versatile.pub/deske.html|title=Discovering English with Sketch Engine : a corpus-based approach to language exploration. Workbook and glossary|last=Thomas|first=James|date=March 2016|publisher=Versatile|isbn=9788026095798|location=Brno|language=en}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} * [http://www.sketchengine.co.uk/ Sketch Engine website] * [http://www.sketchengine.co.uk/corpora/ List of corpora available in Sketch Engine]
